title: 106_hr1829
content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force. The Air Force manages the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary, with administrative responsibility under the Chief of Staff of the Air Force and a National Board of Directors appointed by the Secretary of the Air Force. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol includes general officers of the Air Force, senior civilian employees of the Department of the Air Force, and members appointed from the volunteer Civil Air Patrol membership. The chairman of the Board is the senior active duty Air Force officer. The Board appoints a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General for the Civil Air Patrol. The Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General of the Civil Air Patrol report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the National Board of Directors. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The appointment or assignment of members is not restricted by laws prohibiting active duty members or civilian employees from managing non-Federal entities. An officer or enlisted member of the Air Force appointed to duty in a Civil Air Patrol management position shall not receive any compensation other than regular military pay. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors can utilize Civil Air Patrol employees and volunteers as needed for administration and noncombat mission support. The Civil Air Patrol employees are not considered Federal employees and are not subject to Federal employment laws. However, the Secretary of the Air Force can set conduct standards for them. Funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to specific financial regulations. The Civil Air Patrol's powers, including adopting a constitution, are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. A clerical amendment was made to the table of sections in the chapter. The Civil Air Patrol's powers are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. Air Force role in management and assistance by other agencies are highlighted.
